messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 64 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Pseudorandomness, symmetry, smoothing: I

Paper Abstract: Abstract We prove several new results about bounded uniform and small-bias distributions. A main message is that, small-bias, even perturbed with noise, does not fool several classes of tests better than bounded uniformity. We prove this for threshold tests, small-space algorithms, and small-depth circuits. In particular, we obtain small-bias distributions that ‚Ä¢ achieve an optimal lower bound on their statistical distance to any bounded-uniform distribution. This closes a line of research initiated by Alon, Goldreich, and Mansour in 2003, and improves on a result by O‚ÄôDonnell and Zhao. ‚Ä¢ have heavier tail mass than the uniform distribution. This answers a question posed by several researchers including Bun and Steinke. ‚Ä¢ rule out a popular paradigm for constructing pseudorandom generators, originating in a 1989 work by Ajtai and Wigderson. This again answers a question raised by several researchers. For branching programs, our result matches a bound by Forbes and Kelley. Our small-bias distributions above are symmetric. We show that the xor of any two symmetric small-bias distributions fools any bounded function. Hence our examples cannot be extended to the xor of two small-bias distributions, another popular paradigm whose power remains unknown. We also generalize and simplify the proof of a result of Bazzi.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 64 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 64"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Testing k-wise and almost k-wise independence",
        "A fast and simple randomized algorithm for the maximal independent set problem",
        "Almost kùëòk-wise independence versus kùëòk-wise independence",
        "Asymptotic Tail Bound and Applications",
        "Œ£11subscriptsuperscriptŒ£11\\Sigma^{1}_{1}-formulae on finite structures",
        "Deterministic simulation of probabilistic constant-depth circuits",
        "Polylogarithmic independence can fool DNF formulas",
        "Entropy of weight distributions of small-bias spaces and pseudobinomiality",
        "Weight distribution of cosets of small codes with good dual properties",
        "Pseudorandomness for width-2 branching programs",
        "On k-wise independent distributions and boolean functions",
        "Bounded independence versus symmetric tests",
        "Fourier growth of structured ùîΩ2subscriptùîΩ2\\mathbb{F}_{2}-polynomials and applications",
        "Polylogarithmic independence fools AC00{}^{\\mbox{0}} circuits",
        "Weighted polynomial approximations: limits for learning and pseudorandomness",
        "Pseudorandom bits for polynomials",
        "The bit extraction problem or t-resilient functions (preliminary version)",
        "Fractional pseudorandom generators from any Fourier level",
        "Pseudorandom generators from polarizing random walks",
        "Pseudorandom generators from the second Fourier level and applications to AC0 with parity gates",
        "Improved pseudorandomness for unordered branching programs through local monotonicity",
        "New PRGs for unbounded-width/adaptive-order read-once branching programs",
        "Elements of information theory",
        "Universal classes of hash functions",
        "Bounded independence fools halfspaces",
        "Near-optimal pseudorandom generators for constant-depth read-once formulas",
        "Log-seed pseudorandom generators via iterated restrictions",
        "Pseudorandomness, symmetry, smoothing: II",
        "Pseudorandom generators for read-once branching programs, in any order",
        "Pseudorandomness via the discrete fourier transform",
        "Pseudorandom generators for read-once acc^0",
        "Better pseudorandom generators from milder pseudorandom restrictions",
        "Concentration for limited independence via inequalities for the elementary symmetric polynomials",
        "Theory of unconditional pseudorandom generators",
        "Bounded independence plus noise fools products",
        "On the distance distribution of codes",
        "Survey of binary Krawtchouk polynomials",
        "Nonnegative quadratic forms and bounds on orthogonal polynomials",
        "A moment ratio bound for polynomials and some extremal properties of Krawchouk polynomials and Hamming spheres",
        "Fourier bounds and pseudorandom generators for product tests",
        "Krawtchouk polynomials and universal bounds for codes and designs in Hamming spaces",
        "Some limitations of the sum of small-bias distributions",
        "More on bounded independence plus noise: Pseudorandom generators for read-once polynomials",
        "New upper bounds on the rate of a code via the Delsarte-MacWilliams inequalities",
        "Pseudorandom generators for width-3 branching programs",
        "Small-bias spaces for group products",
        "Pseudorandom generators for space-bounded computation",
        "Small-bias probability spaces: efficient constructions and applications",
        "Analysis of Boolean Functions",
        "On Closeness to kùëòk-Wise Uniformity",
        "Hypercontractivity of spherical averages in Hamming space",
        "A simple proof of Bazzi‚Äôs theorem",
        "Factorial experiments derivable from combinatorial arrangements of arrays",
        "Pseudorandomness for regular branching programs via Fourier analysis",
        "Quasilinear time list-decodable codes for space bounded channels",
        "Pseudorandomness and Fourier-growth bounds for width-3 branching programs",
        "Tight bounds on the fourier spectrum of AC0",
        "Personal communication",
        "A Maclaurin type inequality",
        "Pseudorandomness",
        "On approximate majority and probabilistic time",
        "Correlation bounds against polynomials, a survey",
        "Pseudorandom bits and lower bounds for randomized turing machines",
        "Mathematics of the impossible: The uncharted complexity of computation"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 64 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Pseudorandomness, symmetry, smoothing: I, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
